S3.T1.caption: Table I: Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria.
S3.T1.table:
Inclusion criteria
1. Papers that propose TRSs with a certain degree of configuration.
2. Peer-reviewed papers published in conferences and journals.
3. Works published within the last 10 years.
Exclusion criteria
1. Papers that propose RS for other application domains.
2. Papers not written in English.
3. Short papers, posters, and tutorials (4-6 pages).
4. Out-of-scope papers, e.g., surveys or empirical studies on TRS
references: In addition, during the planning phase, we also defined the inclusion and exclusion criteria as seen in Table I.

The retrieving papers process. started with the search query that returned 203 papers.
The process of removing duplicates excluded 33 works, bringing the total number
to 170. Subsequently, we selected papers based on their titles, abstracts, and keywords, thus further excluding 17 works. The final step implies the application of the inclusion and exclusion criteria over 153 works.
We ended up with 40 primary studies that are reported in Table II. For each approach, we elicited four different aspects, aiming to characterize the current trends and identify possible challenges in configuring TRSs, described as follows:

To answer this question, we carefully analyzed the underpinning algorithm used in the approaches presented in Table II. Discussing in depth each algorithm presented in the selected approach is out of the scope of this paper. Instead, we focus on identifying i) the main techniques used to implement the TRS and ii) the type of travel recommendations that they support. As shown in Table II, we categorize them into seven different high-level categories.

To answer this question, we carefully analyzed the underpinning algorithm used in the approaches presented in Table II. Discussing in depth each algorithm presented in the selected approach is out of the scope of this paper. Instead, we focus on identifying i) the main techniques used to implement the TRS and ii) the type of travel recommendations that they support. As shown in Table II, we categorize them into seven different high-level categories.

To answer this question, we discuss the kind of data mostly used in the TRSs approaches identified in Section III-A, i.e., historical (H) and real-time (RT) data. While we do not focus on data structure, we focus on better characterizing the collected papers in terms of i) what are the most used information considering the application context and ii) how the identified approaches manage the dynamic context information to update the recommendation items accordingly. By looking at Table II, it is evident that the majority of the analyzed TRSs do not manage RT data, i.e., only nine works out of forty exploit them to perform the travel recommendations. By focusing on those approaches, we report that the majority of them consider real-time data related to users rather than the context itself. For instance, in this respect, Kotsopoulos et al. [28] dynamically update the user’s location during cruise travel to adjust the recommendation at run-time. Similarly, Alenezi and Hirtle [28] dynamically update the user’s location during cruise travel to adjust the recommendation at run-time. Similarly, Alenezi and Hirtle [51] collect the attractions visited by the users while the system is running to adjust the recommendation compared to similar travelers. On the contrary, only a few approaches move a step forward by analyzing also further data than users’ behavior. In this respect, Xu et al. [51] collect the attractions visited by the users while the system is running to adjust the recommendation compared to similar travelers. On the contrary, only a few approaches move a step forward by analyzing also further data than users’ behavior. In this respect, Xu et al. [30] combine the duration time of the travel with the user behavior sequence while Chiang and Haung [30] combine the duration time of the travel with the user behavior sequence while Chiang and Haung [52] consider travel delays in their custom scheduling optimization model. Concerning the encoding technique, our investigation reveals that the topics modeling approach and attention layers are the most adopted techniques by the providers. [52] consider travel delays in their custom scheduling optimization model. Concerning the encoding technique, our investigation reveals that the topics modeling approach and attention layers are the most adopted techniques by the providers.

This section discusses threats to validity that may hamper the outcomes of the study [65]. [65]. Construct validity is related to the process followed to collect and analyze the current literature. Our study may miss relevant approaches in the TRS domain, also due to the problem faced with ACM, and the selection phase might be biased. To mitigate the former, we followed well-established guidelines to perform the SMS, by considering three different digital libraries. Moreover, as regards the ACM digital library, we utilized Scopus, which typically contains many duplicate results from ACM. Concerning the latter, we created two independent groups of authors, i.e., the first two authors collected and analyzed the papers to extract the features discussed in Table II and the last two revised the table, through multiple iterations, searching and solving possible misalignment. Concerning internal validity, i.e., possible threats to the employed methodology, the selection of the keywords for querying the digital libraries may lead to an incomplete landscape of the problem, i.e., missing relevant papers. To cope with this, we carefully design the used search string by considering synonyms, and we exploit the advanced search feature of the three search engines. External validity concerns the generalizability of the study i.e., to what extent the findings can be generalized inside or outside of the considered population. To address this, we rigorously adhere to the SMS guidelines [10]. Furthermore, we manually extract and compare the selected approaches in terms of relevant features for the providers. While we narrowed down the scope to assess the configuration features offered by existing TRSs, the identified features are generic enough to be applied to additional classes of recommender systems. [10]. Furthermore, we manually extract and compare the selected approaches in terms of relevant features for the providers. While we narrowed down the scope to assess the configuration features offered by existing TRSs, the identified features are generic enough to be applied to additional classes of recommender systems. Conclusion validity represents threats that could affect the relation between the study and the observed findings. We carefully read all the selected approaches, and we report relevant descriptive statistics to better represent the population.
